metadata.title: 6.7 Modelling with Sinusoidal Functions
metadata.creator: Thiago
metadata.abstract: This document is for testing purposes only. The material that is presented here should be treated as an example only.

section.p: The periodic nature of sinusoidal functions makes them useful in modelling many real-life situations that involve periodic motion (pendulum, spring-mass systems, ocean tides) and rotation (motors, alternating current, wheels).

column.p: justify0.95 The alternating half-day cycles of the rise and fall of oceans are called tides. Tides in Aberdeen, Scotland caused the water level to rise 4 m above mean sea level and drop to 1.0 m above mean sea level. The tide completes one cycle approximately every 12 hours.
justify0.95 Assume the height of water with respect to mean sea level to be modeled by a cosine function.
justify0.95 The equation of Graph 1 is $ y = cos (10x) $ . Create a graph (Graph 2) using the sliders to model the tides in Aberdeen, Scotland over a 24-hour period.

stack.p: A very (un)lucky rider was at the highest position, 166 m above the ground, on the High Roller Ferris wheel in Las Vegas, when the power went out. This Ferris wheel has a radius of 78 m and it travels one revolution every 30 minutes.

column.p: Find a sine function to model the rider’s height, in metres, with respect to time, in minutes, once power is back on.

column.p: How far would this rider have travel when he reached the lowest position?

The rider was travelling along the circumference of the Ferris wheel. The distance between the highest and lowest position is half the circumference.
Thus, $ d = \frac{1}{2}\left ( 2\pi r \right ) = 78\pi $ meters.
